item.title: Fed’s Powell Should Be Investigated by Congress, FHFA Head Says
item.description: Bill Pulte, who leads the Federal Housing Finance Agency, called on Congress to investigate Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, alleging that his recent testimony to the Senate about the central bank’s planned renovations to its headquarters was “deceptive.”
item.dc:creator: Paige Smith

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, arrives for a Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 25, 2025. Powell said a proposal to eliminate the interest paid to banks that deposit cash at the central bank would not save money, and moving back to a scarce reserves regime would be challenging and risk volatility.

item.title: Carney Meets With Automakers as Canada’s Factories Show Tariff Strain
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney is meeting with automotive executives Wednesday to discuss how to help auto plants that have been choked by US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: Canada's prime minister Mark Carney

item.title: Trump Announces Vietnam Trade Deal With 20% Import Tariff
item.description: President Donald Trump said he had reached a trade deal with Vietnam following weeks of intense diplomacy between the nations and ahead of a deadline next week that would have seen higher tariffs imposed on the country’s imports.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Stevens, Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen, Jennifer A Dlouhy

item.title: Mexico Passes Security Bills Modeled on Sheinbaum’s Approach
item.description: Mexico’s Senate approved several government-backed security bills late Tuesday that aim to bolster crime fighting by expanding investigation and intelligence capacities, an approach the opposition says risks allowing invasive surveillance.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Omar Garcia Harfuch.

item.title: France Urgently Needs to Get a Grip on Finances, Auditor Warns
item.description: France must urgently take steps to rein in public finances or soon be forced into painful austerity, the country’s audit court said, highlighting the difficulties for a minority government already at risk of collapse over fiscal plans.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

item.title: Beijing Braces for US Trade Deals That Aim to Shut Out China
item.description: The trade truce between Washington and Beijing may be holding for now, but China is increasingly wary about what’s happening elsewhere: US efforts to forge deals that could isolate Chinese firms from global supply chains.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes and container ships at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai.

item.title: Kristi Noem Looks to Fire Homeland Security Workers ‘Who Don’t Like Us’
item.description: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem is seeking advice on “how to fire people who don’t like us” as she moves to overhaul a workforce that she complained “hasn’t been required to do much.”
item.dc:creator: Ellen M Gilmer

media:content.media:description: Kristi Noem, secretary of the US Department of Homeland Security (DHS), during a Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Homeland Security hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. The hearing is reviewing the fiscal year 2026 budget requests for the US Department of Homeland Security.

item.title: UK Markets Slide as Doubts Swirl Over Chancellor Reeves’s Future
item.description: UK markets tumbled, with the rout spilling into global bond markets, as speculation about a possible exit by Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves made investors nervous about the state of Britain’s finances.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie

item.title: Argentine Judge Allows Lula to Visit Kirchner Under House Arrest
item.description: A federal judge granted former Argentine President Cristina Kirchner’s request for Brazil’s leftist leader, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, to visit her this week in Buenos Aires while she’s under house arrest.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Gillespie

media:content.media:description: Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner meets with Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in Buenos Aires in 2015. Photographer: Juan Mabromata/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Romania Pushes Austerity Plan to Cut EU’s Widest Budget Gap
item.description: Romania’s premier unveiled a package of tax hikes and wage freezes that aims to cut the budget deficit to below 6% of GDP next year and avoid a credit rating downgrade to junk.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: Ilie Bolojan

item.title: Starmer’s Aides Back Reeves After Tears Prompt UK Selloff
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s aides scrambled to express support for Rachel Reeves after his chancellor’s tearful appearance in the House of Commons spurred a UK market selloff amid speculation about her future.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Joe Mayes, Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer and Rachel Reeves in the House of Commons, on July 2.

item.title: Romanian Pro-Russian Ex-Presidential Frontrunner to Face Trial
item.description: Romania’s far-right former presidential frontrunner Calin Georgescu, whose shock victory in last year’s first-found ballot triggered a months-long political crisis, was sent to trial by prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Calin Georgescu gives a statement to media in Izvorani, Romania, on Nov. 26. Photographer: Andrei Pungovschi/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Meets GOP Hardliners as Tax Bill Hits Resistance in House
item.description: President Donald Trump is meeting with a faction of conservative lawmakers at the White House who have threatened to sink his signature tax legislation over its $3.4 trillion price tag as lawmakers cast doubt on whether it can pass by July 4.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: Rep. Andy Harris accompanied by Rep. Chip Roy speaks to the media about the "One, Big, Beautiful Bill" at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, on May 21.

item.title: Nigerian Opposition Alliance Names Interim Leaders Ahead of Vote
item.description: Nigeria’s main opposition parties, which have agreed to unite to contest 2027 elections under the banner of the little-known African Democratic Congress, appointed two interim leaders to steer preparations for their campaign.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Olurounbi

media:content.media:description: A supporter of Labour Party displays a flag during march ahead of the 2023 general elections in Abuja, Nigeria.

item.title: Dutch Pensions Overhaul to Move 11 Million to New System in Just Six Months
item.description: Nearly 11 million people in the Netherlands will switch to a new retirement plan from January 2026, as the country embarks on a pension overhaul that’s widely expected to spur volatility across European bond markets.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom, Sarah Jacob, Alice Atkins

item.title: Key Ukrainian Allies Are Shifting Focus to Other Priorities
item.description: Some of Ukraine’s allies are shifting their focus elsewhere just as the war-battered nation struggles with a fresh volley of missile and drone attacks in its fourth summer of Russia’s full-scale invasion.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Andra Timu, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: A damaged apartment building following a Russian combined missile and drone attack, in Kyiv on June 17. Photographer: Efrem Lukatsky/AP Photo

item.title: Paramount Settles Trump’s ‘60 Minutes’ Suit for $16 Million
item.description: Paramount Global reached a settlement with President Donald Trump over a lawsuit that alleged election interference by the company’s CBS news network when it showed two different versions of a 60 Minutes interview with then-Vice President Kamala Harris in October.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Miller, Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: The CBS headquarters in New York.

item.title: Mozambique President Urges Total LNG Restart Despite Risks
item.description: Mozambican President Daniel Chapo said his government and private companies will have to collectively ensure the necessary security is in place to enable TotalEnergies SE to restart construction of a $20 billion gas project that has stalled due to a militant insurgency — and even then risks will remain.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro, Matthew Hill

media:content.media:description: Mozambican President Daniel Chapo

item.title: Trump Says Israel Agrees to Terms for 60-Day Gaza Ceasefire
item.description: US President Donald Trump said Israel has agreed to a 60-day ceasefire in Gaza and that the plan will now be presented to Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Derek Wallbank, Ethan Bronner

media:content.media:description: Palestinians carry sacks of flour from an aid distribution point in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. Some of Israel’s closest European allies, including Germany, the UK and France, have grown increasingly critical of its prosecution of the war, which has destroyed much of the coastal strip and sparked what international aid agencies say is a hunger crisis.

item.title: US Halts Key Ukraine Weapons Deliveries Amid Russian Barrage
item.description: The Trump administration is halting the transfer of artillery rounds and air defenses to Ukraine, depriving the country of much-needed weapons as it endures stepped-up missile and drone attacks from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Courtney McBride

media:content.media:description: A Patriot air defence system. Photographer: Sergei Gapon/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Why Thailand’s Shinawatra Dynasty Is on the Brink of Losing Power Once Again
item.description: The billionaire dynasty that has dominated Thailand’s politics for more than two decades is on the cusp of being ousted from high office yet again. Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra was suspended by the Constitutional Court pending a ruling on allegations of ethical misconduct.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra, Thailand’s prime minister

item.title: South African Treasury Warns Against Changing SARB Ownership
item.description: Changing the ownership structure of the South African Reserve Bank could generate fears among investors about expropriation and create more uncertainty about property rights, according to the National Treasury.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vecchiatto

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian carries a colorful umbrella as she passes street traders on a road near the headquarters of the South African Reserve Bank, center, in the central business district (CBD) in Pretoria, South Africa, on Tuesday, Dec. 15, 2015. South Africa's new Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan said he'll shore up public finances to regain market trust and show credit-rating companies the government is serious about managing debt.

item.title: Taiwanese President Lai Chooses to Confront China
item.description: Lai is touring the island urging residents to unite against growing pressure from Beijing
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee

media:content.media:description: Lai Ching-te, Taiwan's president, center, and Han Kuo-yu, president of the Legislative Yuan, second right, during the National Day celebration in Taipei, Taiwan, on Thursday, Oct. 10, 2024. Lai indicated in a speech that he would stand up to the challenges posed by China, comments likely to elicit a sharp response from Beijing. Photographer: An Rong Xu/Bloomberg

item.title: Bank of Portugal’s Centeno Says He’d Like to Serve a New Term
item.description: Bank of Portugal Governor Mario Centeno said that he wants to continue serving as head of the country’s central bank, days before his first term is set to end.
item.dc:creator: Joao Lima, Francine Lacqua

media:content.media:description: Mario Centeno, governor of Banco de Portugal during a Bloomberg Television interview at the Kansas City Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole Economic Policy Symposium in Moran, Wyoming, US, on Friday, Aug. 23, 2024. Chair Jerome Powell said the time has come for the Federal Reserve to cut its key policy rate, affirming expectations that officials will begin lowering borrowing costs next month and making clear his intention to prevent further cooling in the labor market. Photographer: Natalie Behring/Bloomberg

item.title: Bangladesh Court Sentences Ex-PM Hasina to Prison for Contempt
item.description: A tribunal in Bangladesh has sentenced former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina to six months in prison for contempt of court, the first verdict in any case against her since her government collapsed in August last year.
